abstract: The story, widely circulated in Beijing, went like this: Bo Guagua, the younger son of the fallen Chinese Communist Party leader, Bo Xilai, arrived one evening last spring at the home of the United States ambassador. He was there to pick up one of the ambassador's daughters for a dinner date, and was supposedly wearing a tuxedo and driving a red Ferrari. "I did not drive at all that evening, and certainly did not sit in a red sports car," Bo Guagua now says, in his first interview since his father was deposed and his parents were put under investigation. "I'm not sure where this story comes from."

headline.main: Details Are Refuted in Tale of Bo Guagua's Red Ferrari
